definition: A system of government where power is held by the people, usually through elected representatives.
A state in which power is held by the people and their elected representatives, with an elected leader rather than a monarch.
A set of fundamental principles or laws that govern a country or organization.
Laws created or enacted by a legislative body.
The supreme power or authority of a state to govern itself.
A system of ideas and ideals, especially one that forms the basis of political theory and policy.
A form of government where a king or queen rules.
A government ruled by a small group of powerful individuals.
A political system where individual freedoms are limited and power is concentrated in the hands of a leader or elite.
Information used to influence public opinion, often biased or misleading.
The practice of managing international relations through negotiation and dialogue.
A system of government with many departments and officials.
A political system where power is divided between a central government and regional governments.
A planned series of actions aimed at winning an election or influencing policy.
A legislative body in some countries, especially the UK.
The process of charging a public official with misconduct.
A group of voters in a specific area who elect a representative.
Attempting to influence decisions made by officials, often by special interest groups.
A direct vote by the public on a specific issue or policy.
A state of society without government or law.
